welcome_message: Welcome back to your health dashboard
start_chatting: Start chatting with our AI assistant
consult_doctor: Consult a dermatologist for proper diagnosis
select_image_prompt: Tap the camera icon to select an image
please_select_image: Please select an image to scan
health_tip_1: Stay hydrated by drinking at least 8 glasses of water daily.
health_tip_2: Avoid excessive sun exposure to protect your skin.
health_tip_3: Use moisturizer daily for dry skin.
health_tip_4: Eat fruits and vegetables rich in Vitamin C.
health_tip_5: Don't skip sunscreen when going outside.
emergency_help_description: If you need urgent assistance, please press the button below

descriptions.actinic_keratoses: A precancerous skin condition caused by long-term sun exposure.
descriptions.basal_cell_carcinoma: The most common type of skin cancer, often appearing as a waxy bump or flat, flesh-colored lesion.
descriptions.benign_keratosis: Noncancerous skin growths that develop from skin cells called keratinocytes.
descriptions.dermatofibroma: A common, benign skin growth that usually appears as a firm, raised nodule.
descriptions.melanoma: The most serious type of skin cancer that develops in the cells that produce melanin.
descriptions.melanocytic_nevi: Common moles, which are usually harmless but should be monitored for changes.
descriptions.vascular_lesions: Abnormal growths or malformations of blood vessels in the skin.

remedies.actinic_keratoses: Cryotherapy, topical medications, or surgical removal. Regular skin checks are recommended.
remedies.basal_cell_carcinoma: Surgical removal, Mohs surgery, or radiation therapy. Sun protection is crucial.
remedies.benign_keratosis: Usually no treatment needed, but can be removed if bothersome through cryotherapy or curettage.
remedies.dermatofibroma: Typically doesn't require treatment, but can be surgically removed if desired.
remedies.melanoma: Surgical removal is the primary treatment. Early detection is critical for better outcomes.
remedies.melanocytic_nevi: No treatment needed unless changes are observed. Regular skin checks are recommended.
remedies.vascular_lesions: Treatment options include laser therapy, sclerotherapy, or surgery, depending on the type and location.

doctor_recommendations.basal_cell_carcinoma: Dermatologist or Mohs surgeon for treatment options.
doctor_recommendations.benign_keratosis: Dermatologist if the lesion changes in appearance or becomes symptomatic.
doctor_recommendations.dermatofibroma: Dermatologist if the growth changes or causes discomfort.
doctor_recommendations.melanoma: Immediate consultation with a dermatologist or surgical oncologist.
doctor_recommendations.melanocytic_nevi: Dermatologist for regular skin checks and evaluation of any changing moles.
doctor_recommendations.vascular_lesions: Dermatologist or vascular specialist for evaluation and treatment options.

common_questions.how_to_prevent_skin_cancer: How can I prevent skin cancer?
common_questions.when_to_see_doctor: When should I see a doctor about a mole?
common_questions.skin_self_exam: How to perform a skin self-exam?
common_questions.risk_factors: What are the risk factors for skin cancer?

answers.skin_cancer: Skin cancer is the abnormal growth of skin cells, most often developing on skin exposed to the sun. The main types are basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.
prevention_tips: Use broad-spectrum sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher
Seek shade when the sun is strongest (10 a.m. to 4 p.m.)
Wear protective clothing, including a hat and UV-blocking sunglasses
warning_signs: Asymmetry: One half doesn't match the other
Border: Irregular, scalloped, or poorly defined border
Color: Varies from one area to another
Diameter: Larger than 6mm (about the size of a pencil eraser)
Evolving: Mole or skin lesion looks different from the rest or is changing in size, shape, or color
